docs.abstract: Chinese officials and family of late Communist Party chief Zhao Ziyang have agreed to hold public burial service for him, resolving political tensions that arose after his death; he was purged after opposing 1989 crackdown on dissent (M)

headline.main: Accord on Zhao Funeral Is Reported in China

docs.snippet: Chinese officials and the family of Zhao Ziyang, the late Communist Party chief, have agreed to hold a public burial service.
docs.lead_paragraph: Chinese officials and the family of Zhao Ziyang, the late Communist Party chief, have agreed to hold a public burial service for Mr. Zhao on Saturday, resolving a prolonged standoff, people who had been told about the arrangement said Thursday. The agreement between top Communist Party officials and the children of Mr. Zhao is a step toward resolving the political tensions that arose after the death of the former prime minister and party chief, who was purged after opposing the 1989 crackdown on dissent.

docs.abstract: Photograph of passengers disembarking in Beijing from first direct flight between Taiwan and China in 56 years; China and Taiwan agreed to series of flights marking Lunar New Year
docs.snippet: Photograph of passengers disembarking in Beijing from first direct flight between Taiwan and China in 56 years; China and Taiwan agreed to series of flights marking Lunar New Year

docs.abstract: Chinese officials, fearing instability, initially suppressed nearly all information about death of Zhao Zhiyang, purged for opposing use of force against democracy protesters in 1989, but party was forced to organize public funeral when several retired Politburo members and Communist Party elders said they wished to pay their last respects; family demanded service appropriate for state leader and refused to endorse eulogy condemning Zhao; tightly restricted event underscores how much party lives in fear of its own historical ghosts; photo (M)

headline.main: China's Fear of Ghosts: Balancing Stability and Dissent

docs.snippet: China's top leaders struggled to find the right balance in managing the politically explosive death of Zhao Ziyang, who was memorialized Saturday.
docs.lead_paragraph: Deng Xiaoping, China's late paramount leader, famously declared after he consolidated power in the early 1980's that his predecessor, Mao Zedong, was 70 percent good and 30 percent bad. With that numerical coda, the Communist Party closed a historical debate that had threatened to tear it apart. Hu Jintao, general secretary of the Communist Party and China's top leader, assigned no precise ratio to assess his late predecessor, Zhao Ziyang. But Mr. Hu clearly struggled to find the right balance in managing the politically explosive death of Mr. Zhao, who was officially memorialized and cremated on Saturday.

docs.abstract: Photo of two Chinese men impersonating Chinese leaders Deng Xiaoping and Mao Zedong, as part of Beijing's celebration of Chinese New Year

headline.main: Beijing Does A Double Take (They're Not Wax)

docs.snippet: Photo of two Chinese men impersonating Chinese leaders Deng Xiaoping and Mao Zedong, as part of Beijing's celebration of Chinese New Year

docs.abstract: John Rockwell review of Beijing Modern Dance Co production of Rear Light, based on rock band Pink Floyd's The Wall, at Joyce Theater; choreography is by Li Hanzhong and Ma Bo; photo (M)

headline.main: A Chinese Perspective On Exploring Pink Floyd

docs.snippet: The troupe's abstract dance based on Pink Floyd's "The Wall," as seen at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday, revealed the gulf between two highly disparate cultures.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Beijing Modern Dance Company, the most prominent of the new wave of Chinese modern dance troupes, made its New York debut last night at the Joyce Theater and won the expected ovation. Rightly so, in that the company includes some forceful, energetic dancers and presents its works (or at least the work presented last night) with high technical accomplishment. That said, ''Rear Light'' is for all its intermittent brilliance an odd duck of a dance. It is based on ''The Wall'' by the cult English psychedelic rock band Pink Floyd -- or more precisely, and this makes a big difference, on the film that the director Alan Parker made of the album and its stage show in 1982.

docs.abstract: China formally calls for nuclear weapons-free Korean peninsula and urges North Korea to return to regional talks regarding its nuclear program, following North Korea's announcement that it has manufactured nuclear weapons; sentiment is echoed in state-run media and Internet chatrooms; broad criticism is important because China has tended to take protective position on North Korea (M)

headline.main: China Calls on North Korea To Return to Regional Talks

docs.snippet: The Chinese Foreign Ministry has said little about North Korea's declaration that it has nuclear weapons, but the state-controlled news media have been uncommonly critical.

byline.original: By KEITH BRADSHER and JAMES BROOKE; Keith Bradsher reported from Beijing for this article, and James Brooke from Tokyo

docs.lead_paragraph: China on Sunday publicly called for the Korean peninsula to be free of nuclear weapons and urged North Korea to return to regional talks regarding its nuclear program. State-run Chinese media and censored Internet chat rooms were uncommonly critical of Pyongyang for having announced Thursday that it had manufactured nuclear weapons. The official New China News Agency reported Sunday morning that Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing of China had spoken by phone on Saturday night with Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice. Mr. Li called for the regional negotiations to resume as soon as possible and for the ''denuclearization'' of the peninsula, the agency said.

docs.abstract: John Rockwell comment on New York debut of Beijing Modern Dance Company production of Rear Light; piece is set to soundtrack of 1982 movie The Wall, itself based on recording by band Pink Floyd; photos (M)

headline.main: A Lot of Knowledge Is Dangerous, Too

docs.snippet: How best to regard the Beijing Modern Dance Company's "Rear Light," a dance that regards a film that regards an album?
docs.lead_paragraph: THERE must be a fruitful middle ground between ignorance and knowledge, but where? Where is the ideal synthesis between knowing next to nothing in advance about a work of art, and hence appreciating it fresh, ''on its own terms,'' and so overpreparing that all kinds of inappropriate criteria distort one's perceptions? Such thoughts came to mind after the New York debut of the Beijing Modern Dance Company at the Joyce Theater earlier this month. About the excellence of the dancers, there could be no question. But it was less certain how an audience member should have best prepared for encountering ''Rear Light,'' the sole work on the program.

docs.abstract: Why We Travel column; Hanny Layantara comments on why he is vacationing with wife and friends in Beijing, China
docs.snippet: Hanny Layantara, 42, a pastor from Surabaya, Indonesia, with (left to right) his wife, Agnes Maria, and his friends Rita Halim and Anton Thedy. It's been a long time since we've seen snow. For me, it was back in Minneapolis in 1985. My wife, she saw
docs.lead_paragraph: Hanny Layantara, 42, a pastor from Surabaya, Indonesia, with (left to right) his wife, Agnes Maria, and his friends Rita Halim and Anton Thedy. It's been a long time since we've seen snow. For me, it was back in Minneapolis in 1985. My wife, she saw snow just once in Europe. We came to Beijing in the winter because it's good to go on the Great Wall during the cold weather instead of going in the summer, when you'll be sweating all the time. At the Forbidden City, the wind was blowing quite hard and we were shaking. These guys were picking up all the snow and then they just tried to hit me. They said: ''This is the right time to throw snow at the pastor. You'll never have another chance to throw snow at the pastor.'' As told to Seth Kugel

docs.abstract: Tung Chee-hwa, Hong Kong's chief executive, reportedly will resign in face of heavy criticism of his administration from Beijing government and local business community (M)

headline.main: Top Hong Kong Official Is Said to Be Close to Resigning Post

docs.snippet: Tung Chee-hwa, Hong Kongs chief executive, has come under heavy criticism from Beijing and local residents alike.
docs.lead_paragraph: Tung Chee-hwa, Hong Kong's chief executive, is preparing to step down after coming under heavy criticism from Beijing and from local residents, two people familiar with the decision said Tuesday and Wednesday. Both declined to detail when he might resign. But a newspaper in Hong Kong, The Standard, citing unidentified sources in Beijing, reported Wednesday that Mr. Tung had submitted his resignation more than two weeks ago and that it had been accepted at an emergency meeting of the Chinese Communist Party Politburo.

docs.abstract: China's leaders introduce bill that would effectively pre-authorize military action if Taiwan takes concrete steps toward formal independence; direct challenge seen to Pres Chen Shui-bian, who has made constitutional change goal of second term; bill amounts to political commitment by new Chinese leadership under Hu Jintao to act decisively if Taiwan tries to solidify existing status; photo of Chinese official Wang Zhaoquo (M)

headline.main: Beijing Leaders Speak of Force to Keep Taiwan 'Chinese'

docs.snippet: A new bill effectively pre-authorizesmilitary action if Taiwan takes concrete steps toward independence.
docs.lead_paragraph: China's leaders introduced a bill on Tuesday that would effectively pre-authorize military action if Taiwan took concrete steps toward formal independence, a move American officials have said they fear could increase prospects for cross-strait conflict. The legislation specifies that any changes in Taiwan's Constitution seeking to legalize the island's de facto independent status could be a trigger for military action. It is a direct challenge to President Chen Shui-bian of Taiwan, who had made changing the Constitution a paramount goal of his second term in office.
